plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the Barclays 2012 Full-Year Results Analyst and Investor Conference Call. I will now hand you over to Chris Lucas, Group Finance Director.

Good morning and thank you for joining us. As you know, this is an important day for Barclays. We announced the key conclusions for our strategic review this morning and Antony will give a presentation on them this afternoon. The executive committee will be there to answer questions and the event will be webcast. The purpose of this call is to focus purely on the results for 2012. As usual, we're using adjusted numbers to give a better understanding of our underlying performance.

Turning now to the headlines, we've made good progress across most of our businesses during the year. Adjusted profits increased 26% to £7 billion. Total income was up 2% to £29 billion despite Gilt gains of £1.1 billion from the sale of hedging instruments in 2011. Impairment improved 5% to £3.6 billion, mainly as a result of favorable trends in our UK businesses, which resulted in net income growth of 3% to £25.4 billion. We've continued to reduce costs which decreased 3% to £18.5 billion and our capital liquidity and funding remain strong. Our Core Tier 1 ratio was 10.9% and out total capital ratio was 17.1%.

Adjustments to statutory numbers include a £4.6 billion charge on own credit, a provision for PPI of £1.6 billion, an £850 million charge for redress on interest rate hedges, and a gain on BlackRock. As a result, statutory profits were £246 million. The provisions which include additional charges taken in the fourth quarter which we announced last week, £400 million was provided for redress of interest rate hedges. This is based on the FSA's report after a pilot exercise conducted in the fourth quarter. A charge of £600 million was made for PPI. This is largely the result of higher than expected response rates from proactively contacting customers ourselves. The PPI balance sheet provision at the end of the year was £990 million.

Return on equity increased from 6.6% to 7.8%. We'll talk more about our plans to improve this later today. Our four largest businesses all increased returns. There were strong performances from UK RBB and Barclaycard, which reported returns of 16% and 22.1% respectively. The investment bank delivered returns of 13.7% and corporate banking continued its turnaround. Returns there were 5.5%, up from 1.7% in 2011.

Returns by business is shown in an appendix of the slide pack. I've told you we'll be allocating more head office results to the businesses going forward. We'll issue details of this before our first quarter. The business returns we're reporting this morning exclude this allocation so head office is reflected in our group returns.

The group's cost/income ratio improved from 67% to 64%. Adjusted earnings per share increased to £0.345. And we've announced a cash dividend for the fourth quarter of £0.035, bringing the total to £0.065 for the full year. This is up from £0.06 in 2011. We understand the importance of dividends and aim to pursue a progressive policy which Antony will talk about later.
The decrease in net tangible asset value per share mainly reflects the own credit charge, provisions for PPI and interest rate hedges, and other adverse reserve movements.

Turning now to the individual businesses, in UK RBB, profits were up 4% to £1.5 billion. Total income was down 5% to £4.4 billion reflecting the non-recurrence of Gilt gains and a decline in the underlying contribution from structural hedges. Excluding these impacts, income was stable as growth from higher volumes on customer assets and deposits was offset by increased funding cost.

Impairment charges halved to £269 million. This reflects improvements across all portfolios, especially in personal unsecured lending. The loan loss rate also halved to 21 basis points, 90-days arrears on unsecured personal loans improved by 33 basis points to 1.34%. Excluding PPI, costs reduced 1% to £2.7 billion.

At Barclaycard, profits were up 25% to £1.5 billion. Income grew 2% to £4.2 billion. Impairments improved 22% and the loan loss rate was 282 basis points compared to 391 in 2011. 30-day arrear rates improved in both the U.S. and the UK, excluding PPI and goodwill impairments in 2011 costs grew 3%.

In Africa Retail and Business Banking income decreased 12% to £3.2 billion. This is a result of adverse exchange rates and non-recurring Gilt gains. Impairment grew 39% as a result of provisions taken in the second and third quarter on mortgages in the Absa recovery book.

We believe impairment in this book has now stabilized and early arrears are improving across almost all portfolios including mortgages. Costs decreased 10% reflecting currency movements. Profits were down 44% to £468 million.

During the fourth quarter we announced plans to combine the majority of our Barclays African operations with Absa. The terms of the transaction are supported by the independent fairness opinion and will be voted on by Absa shareholders later this month.

Europe Retail and Business Banking made a loss of £239 million, income fell 25%, reflecting the economic environment. Impairment increased 26% or £67 million mainly as a result of deterioration in mortgages. We reduced costs by 31% as savings flowed through from the restructuring in 2011. We also reduced the local funding gap in Europe. Customer assets reduced slightly in euros while deposits increased, notably in Spain.

Turning now to the Investment Bank, profits grew 37% to £4.1 billion. Total income grew 13% to £11.7 billion. Within this, fixed income, currencies and commodities increased 17% to £7.4 billion. Equities and prime services grew 14% to £2 billion and investment banking was up 5% at £2.1 billion. This income growth reflects share gains in many product areas and was achieved despite the 5% reduction in RWAs to £178 billion, and a 33% reduction in daily value at risk to £38 million. Impairment increased from £93 million to £460 million. This increase includes a charge relating to legacy CDO assets. There's also a one-off release of £223 million in 2011.

We reduced the bonus pool and other incentive awards granted in 2012 by 20% while income grew 13% and profits were up 37%. The full impact of this reduction will feed into results in future years due to the IFRS treatment of deferred bonuses.

Our reported costs in 2012 fell 1% to £7.2 billion. Performance costs were down 3% to £1.7 billion despite an increase of £210 million in charges relating to deferrals from prior years. Non-performance costs were broadly in line with 2011 after absorbing £193 million of the LIBOR settlement. Excluding LIBOR, non-performance costs fell 4%.

The costs to net operating income ratio improved from 71% to 64% and the compensation-to-income ratio reduced from 47% to 39%. We continue to reduce our legacy assets. Credit market exposures decreased by almost £6 billion to £9.3 billion and we exited these positions at or above our marks.

We believe that annual trends give a better understanding of performance, but we also report quarterly numbers as we know you'll be interested in them. You can see the quarterly income progression in 2012 has a similar shape to 2011 but at a higher level. Comparing the fourth quarter last year with the third quarter, total income was down only 2% at £2.6 billion despite tougher market conditions.

As we've said before, our flow business model is designed to protect us from downside market risks. As a result, we may outperform in weak markets and underperform in strong markets. You see the fourth quarter as further evidence of this.

Moving down to look at the current quarterly progression by business line, fixed income, currencies and commodities were down just 8% in the fourth quarter. Equities and prime services were down 9% as we grew share despite low market volumes. Investment banking was up 29%.

In Corporate Banking, profits more than doubled to £551 million. Within this, the UK was up 22% to £910 million, losses in Europe reduced to £381 million and other regions reported a small profit compared to a small loss in 2011. Income was down 6% to £2.9 billion. Impairments improved 24% to £872 million. There was a 30% reduction in Spain to £337 million resulting from lower exposure to the property and construction sector. We reduced costs 14% to £1.5 billion.

In Wealth and Investment Management, profits grew 52% to £315 million as our investment in the business gained traction. Income grew 4% to £1.8 billion driven by high net worth business and related increases in both customer loans and deposits. Costs were down 2% despite continued investment. Current assets under management increased 13% to £186 billion mainly as a result of net new assets in the high net worth business.

Losses in head office were £1.1 billion compared to £1 billion in 2011. There was an improvement in the income line of £148 million. This was mainly due to a one-off gain on hedges relating to employee share awards which we closed out in the first quarter.

This was more than offset by an increase in the bank's levy and other operating expenses amounting to – sorry, to £243 million. Operating expenses include £97 million on the LIBOR settlement and financial service compensation scheme charges which increased by £90 million.
Moving on now to capital, liquidity and funding, our Core Tier 1 ratio at the end of 2012 was 10.9% on a Basel 2.5 basis. Our total capital ratio was 17.1% and RWA was slightly down at £387 billion.

Our liquidity position remains strong with a pool of £150 billion. This compares with a wholesale funding maturing this year of £101 billion. At the end of December, we had liquidity coverage ratio of 126% based on the latest Basel trends. We are already compliant with net stable funding ratio proposals.
We had £27 billion of term debt maturing in 2012 reaching £28 billion in term funding, which enabled significant pre-funding of our term maturities this year which are £18 billion.

The issuance included £3 billion of tier 2 contingent capital notes, which are fully allowable as primary loss-absorbing capacity. We also raised £6 billion through the Bank of England's lending – sorry, funding and lending scheme.
Our retail banking, corporate banking, and wealth businesses are largely funded by customer deposits, so loan-to-deposit ratio for these businesses improved from 111% to 102%.

Let's talk to you more about the impact of Basel 3 based on implementation in January. As you know, the implementation didn't take place. To allow comparison with our previous disclosure we've shown the ratio reported at the year-end alongside pro forma ratios as if we had applied Basel 3. We've also included the impact of IFRS changes that apply from January.

Our latest Basel 3 estimates show a pro forma transitional common equity tier 1 ratio of 10.6% as of January 1. We also show the fully-loaded ratio which is 8.2%, a slight increase on the position disclosed at the end of September. Detailed calculations are in the appendix of our slide pack. We continue to believe that we're well-capitalized and we'll discuss our capital structure and targets this afternoon.

Turning now to margins, as I've mentioned before, we look at margins in two parts: customer margins, which drive the vast majority of our own net interest income, and then the secondary margin derived from structural hedges.

I'll start by talking about hedging. Across the group as a whole, the total contribution from structural hedges fell from £3.3 billion to £1.7 billion as expected. This was mainly due to the 2011 Gilt gains which we realized as we shortened the duration of hedges. The reduction in underlying contribution from these hedges is expected to be less pronounced this year.

The businesses which contribute to our net interest margin analysis are Retail and Business Banking, Corporate Banking and Wealth. Overall, margins from these businesses fell 18 basis points to 1.85%. 14 basis points of this decline or £800 million was from the reduced hedge contribution. This shows the relative stability of our customer margins.

Increased volumes, mainly on the liabilities side, broadly offset slight customer margin contraction so that net interest income generated from customers was stable at £9.8 billion. Overall, net interest income from these businesses decreased 7% to £11.2 billion.

Turning now to costs, we reduced overall costs by 3% to £18.5 billion. Performance costs for the group were down 4% to £2.4 billion, while income grew 2% and profits were up 26%. We reduced non-performance costs for the group by 3% to £16.1 billion. This includes the LIBOR settlement of £290 million and bank levy of £345 million. Without these items, the level of non-performance costs would have been £15.5 billion which is in line with our cost savings target. Bonuses and incentive awards granted in 2012 across the group were reduced by 16%. This reflects action taken to reposition our compensation in the marketplace and various conduct issues.

That's all I have to say on the 2012 results. Looking at current trading, it's been a good start to the year across the group in January. So in summary, we're reporting good results for 2012. Adjusted profits grew 26% to £7 billion. Income was up 2% despite Gilt gains of £1.1 billion in 2011. Impairments improved 5% and we reduced costs by 3%. Our capital liquidity and funding remained strong with a Core Tier 1 ratio of 10.9%.
Thanks very much. We look forward to speaking to you again later today and I'm happy to take questions on the results now. Thank you.
Today's first question comes from the line of Chris Manners from Morgan Stanley.
Hi, there. Good morning everyone.
Good morning, Chris.

Yes, I just had a question which was on your Barclaycard impairment charges. I could see the – it's actually been rising for a couple of quarters. And maybe you might be able to just give us an update on what you think of the trajectory there and whether that's something that we should be concerned about. Thanks.

Let me ask Robert Le Blanc who is with me to add to the comment. But my overall view is the performance of Barclaycard in the credit area has been extremely strong and there's nothing that I see that makes me worry about it as we look forward.

I think that's right. Good morning, Chris. We've seen improvements in card impairments over the last couple of years principally in our U.S. and UK portfolios as the economies have improved as well and the card portfolios, of course, are all over the world including Europe and South Africa. So, although they do move around the trend has been positive and I'd say we expect it to remain fairly steady from this point, so no, nothing there particularly concerning.
Okay. Thanks, Robert. Would it be possible maybe just to ask you to expound on how you see the credit outlook across the group in that case?
You certainly can.

Yes, certainly. Just – I'll make just a brief comment on that, if I may. I mean, you'll recognize that we've seen a very significant reduction in impairment over the last three years. But if you look closely, the general trends in the second half of 2012 were broadly steady compared to the first half. And so, the strength of the improvement we've seen has started to steady out, I think, as we had expected and guided you on.

I think the trend issue will be steady across most portfolios in wholesale and retail. There is some room for a little bit further improvement, but my outlook for this year is a broadly steady one with potentially some slight improvement and we think that will come through in the impairment numbers for this year.
Thank you.
Thank you. And today's next question comes from the line of J.P. Crutchley from UBS.
Good morning, chaps. Can you hear me okay?
Good morning, J.P. Yes, we can.

Yes, it's a broader question, I guess, in terms of context for numbers. At the last Financial Policy Committee, clearly, the FSA was sent away to have discussions with the banks on three broad topics: forbearance; making sure legacy costs have been properly put into numbers; and risk-weightings. Clearly, you've taken charges on legacy items and that's pretty apparent. You've talked about in the UK retail results about risk assets going up because of a more comprehensive approach to forbearance. I wonder if you can discuss around that.

And on the third point, on risk-weightings, I wonder if you can maybe just elucidate how that discussion has progressed and can we conclude from this and given that in the strategic statement you talk about increasing dividend policy, but as far as you are concerned, those debates with the FSA on capital and the like are closed and therefore the debate around – for Barclays in particular, though, is likely to be a subject of needing more capital with this debate that's going on between the FSA and FPC is done and dusted?

Let me start and ask Robert to touch on forbearance and then we'll pick RWAs. I think, J.P., in general terms, we share, as you can imagine, pretty much everything with the FSA on an ongoing basis. So they have been with us and briefed on the strategic review that we're talking about later on today, and also those areas of forbearance, RWAs, CVAs and the impairment on certain areas.

Whilst I don't think we'd ever say that they have to make our decisions for us, that's very much our job, we have a constructive dialog with them and over time, understand their position, they understand our position. And you can be sure that we've briefed them as to these results. We've briefed them as to the forward-looking views that we'll be talking about later on, and I think it's a very constructive dialog. How that plays out as we go into the future, only time will tell, but I'm very pleased with where we are at the moment.
Robert?

Thanks. I would only add that when we look at forbearance from a capital point of view, firstly we have been carefully measuring and monitoring the levels of forbearance themselves, which is disclosed in the results this year, and really, what's changed from an RWA point of view is simply the recognition of forbearance as an impairment event or as a default, and that's been changing and being adjusted through our RWA model so it's had an effect during the year.

If I look more generally at RWAs, probably the best place to be is on slide 33 which shows the bridge from £391 billion RWAs at the end of December 2011 and £387 billion at December 2012. And you can see in there there's some quite sizeable individual items of methodology change of £20 billion, operational risk uplift of £18 billion, offset predominantly by business reductions, which are real business reductions including legacy assets of about £28 billion.
Yes.
So there's some big moving parts but it shows that, like most of these things, lots of big moving parts sort of net down to almost no significant change year-on-year.
And on risk weights, has that all sort of been methodology changes or is that something which hasn't changed materially?

It's a mixture of methodology changes. It's a mixture of business reduction where the returns are insufficient. And to give you a flavor, if you look at methodology changes in the £20 billion on slide 33, it's made up of an increased market risk charge, changes to sovereign loss-giving defaults and slotting of mortgages.
Okay. Thank you.
Thank you. And today's next question comes from the line of Michael Helsby from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

Yes, good morning, everyone. I've just got a question on the investment bank's costs. Comp ratio was 39% and your bonus pool was down 15%. One of the ways I look at it is to look at the bonus as a percentage of net revenue and that was 11.5% versus 15.7% last year. And your deferral rates changed slightly. I was wondering if you could give us a little bit more color around how you see both the deferral rate evolving in the next couple of years in the light of your plan, and also whether an 11.5% sort of bonus as a percent of net revenue, if that's now consistent with this sort of the mid-35 comp ratio that you'll be looking for, i.e. can we take 2012 as a reasonable base forward because that makes quite a difference? Thank you.
Let me ask Rich to start and then I'll make a few comments.
Good morning, Michael.
Good morning.

I guess there's a couple of elements to your question. First, I've been on record several times as talking about our comp income ratio I see normalizing in the mid-30s over time. And you have to recall, as I know you know, that what you're looking at is the actual in-year charge that gets hung up with the actual bonus pool in year but over time, I would expect those things to kind of come into line with each other.

Now, that would mean that I would also see the deferral rate decreasing over time. We've had some extraordinary circumstances and for very good reasons had higher than I would say are normal deferrals in the last couple of years. But I would see those decreasing in time. They decreased this year actually.
And as I say, I think over time best-in-class investment banks and banks for that matter will have comp to income ratios in the mid-30s and we're on a journey to get there.

I think when we look at all the different measures of comp to income, yours, Michael, is a new one that we haven't used before. We'll certainly sort that out and if there's anything that we want to add to what we've said, we'll do so.
Okay, thank you.
Your next question today comes from the line of Andrew Coombs from Citigroup.

Good morning. I have a question on slide 35 please, on the pro forma CRD IV capital and RWAs. Two questions related to that, I guess, if I split it up, first on the numerator. If I look at your tangible book value per share, you just reported £0.0373, but adjusting for IAS 19, the £2.5 billion shareholders' equity hit, and IFRS 10, the £0.5 billion shareholders' equity hit, I guess that's pro forma £0.035. But I just wanted to check that both of those aspects are already captured in your fully loaded Core Tier 1 guidance on slide 35?

And then the second half of the question, on your RWA number, back at the nine-month 2012 stage you were guiding to £485 billion of Basel 3 RWAs by the year-end. You're now guiding to £468 billion and the two big moving parts in that look to be the CVA which has dropped from 46 to 29 and securitization which has dropped from 39 to 25. So just intrigued what the big driver of those two changes has been. Thank you.
I think the answer to your first question about whether the accounting changes have been included, the answer is yes, they have.

In terms of RWAs and I think if I heard you right, you're talking about the £468 billion. So there's a number of things in there: there is securitizations as far as the impacts of IFRS 10 goes and the net capital change flows through there as well.

The other area of reduction is CVA. And I think one of the things which is becoming clear to us is the volatility of the CVA number arising from changes in spreads. So, you were very correct in what you were asking. And I think the 268 is a more accurate current view of where the numbers are going to turn out.
Okay. Thank you.
Thank you. And the next question today comes from Raul Sinha of JPMorgan.
Good morning, Chris.
Good morning.

Can I just have one question on UK retail's performance? It seems to be quite good loan growth pickup there in the second half of the year and looking at the Bank of England data, Barclays seems to outperforming the other banks in terms of the FLS [Funding for Lending Scheme] loans extended. Can you comment on how the performance was in Q4 on both absolute balances and margins and how you expect that to trend forward?
You're absolutely right that we think we're taking market share in the FLS. In terms of trends, we've seen an upward trend, and it's particularly noticeable in an upward increase in deposits.

And I think there's not much more to say. We've got a good performance. There's a couple of individual items within there that have a bit of an impact on the fourth quarter. But overall, good volume growth, continued gains, and asset growth. So I don't know whether that fully answers your question, but we're pleased with the performance.

Sure. Chris, I guess my question was more towards the underlying pace or momentum within the business heading into next year and especially as deposit costs come down, are you seeing a pickup in margins? And perhaps I can follow-up later in the day.

Yes. I think we can cover that in more detail later today, but I would say the underlying performance is good. We think there's growth there. We see particular area for growth in volumes of customer deposits which will offset a sort of flat margin that we expect to see. So net-net, flat margin, increased volumes, improved net interest income, and good performance overall.
Thanks very much.
Thank you. And your next question today comes from the line of Manus Costello from Autonomous.

Morning, everyone. My one question, I'll go back to slide 35 please, the pro forma impact. I noticed that you've shifted the PVA adjustment out of the transitional into the fully-phased numbers as of day one, I wonder what's driven that and it obviously doesn't impact those on a fully-phased basis, but do you think it will impact your ability to issue further contingent notes which tend to be based on transitional measures and this obviously is quite a negative for that?

I think it is. This is one of the outcomes of the dialogue we would have had with the FSA where it was thought to make more sense and certainly more prudent to put this in the fully-loaded rather than transitional over a period of time. So you can debate the matter either way, but we think doing what we've done sets out the ratio at the most prudent basis of calculation rather than anything else.
And there's nothing else within the transitional provisions which could come back up into the pre-transitional?
No, not that we're aware of.
Okay. Thanks.
Thank you.
The next question today comes from the line of Ian Gordon from Investec.

Yes, good morning. Just coming back to the UK retail performance and in particular, mortgages. As we heard in the previous question, your balance sheet growth has been strong. I think your mortgage growth across the full year was about £7 billion H2 weighted.

In terms of your current pricing, clearly you're being more aggressive than some of your peers. In 2012, arguably you had it easy while Lloyds and Santander UK were giving away share as fast as they could. Is it your intention going forward to maintain your more aggressive pricing to broadly sustain the pace of balance sheet growth even in a slightly more competitive market?

I think we'd have to look at that on a case by case basis. The important thing from my perspective is that we look at the return being made on the products and we look at the return on equity that we make in the business and any decision we make would make about to be aggressive or not aggressive in terms of pricing would be very dependent upon being able to pass and exceed the return on equity targets that we've set for the business and you will hear more about this afternoon.
Okay. Thank you.
Thank you. And the next question today comes from Andrew Lim of Espirito Santo.
Good morning.
Andrew, good morning.

Just got a few questions, please. Your liquidity coverage ratios, you published 126%. Presumably that's on the new Basel 3 basis. I was wondering if you could give some indication on how you'd like to run that. Would that be closer towards the 100% and therefore, you'd be able to reduce your liquidity pool there?
Secondly, on...
Can I answer that one, Andrew, rather than queue them up? Let's try and answer them one by one. But...
Sure, no problem.

...the answer to that is, it is based on the latest view of the LCR rules and we would expect that 126 to come down, but if it gets down as low as 100, I don't know. We would have to look at that over time, but it would certainly trend it down and that, of course, would have the benefit of reducing the cost of the liquidity pool which is the important thing that we've been aiming to do.
So, I hope that answers your first question.

Okay. No, that's fine. Thank you. On page 35, referring back to the capital disclosure, you're the only UK bank to have this PVA adjustment, £1.2 billion for yourselves. I'm just wondering with what kind of certainty can you say that that's actually applicable going forward? I mean, how much can we take that as a concrete adjustment to be made there?
It feels pretty concrete to me.
Okay. Thank you very much. And then thirdly, could you clarify what your outstanding existing Tier 1 and Tier 2 hybrids are? How much these are?
Bear with us, could we look at that answer and we'll come back to you with a response? This is regarded as about £9 billion.
In aggregate for Tier 1, Tier 2s? Okay.
Yes.
Okay. And then just finally, very straightforward I hope. Could you give a bit more color on the mix of revenues in the head office?

There's a range of things in there. I think the best thing to do is to wait until we've restated with the allocation of head office expenses and income and look at it on a go-forward basis. What I would say is that if you look at the overall head office number, it's been creeping up but when you look at it year-on-year, it has a relatively small impact on the overall group with the exception of the group return on equity. And of course, our objective will be to allocate that out more fully and I think that will be a good time to catch up on the individual component parts of it.
Okay. Many thanks, Chris.
Thank you.
Thank you. And the next question today comes from the line of Fiona Swaffield from RBC.

Good morning. Just a question on the Basel 3 leverage ratio, so I think you're saying within 33-times compared to the £49.5 billion, so you're talking of a balance sheet of £1.6 trillion or below, is that the right way? And could you just take us through what the adjustments are under Basel 3 relative to your just under £1 trillion U.S. GAAP?

I think the answer is yes, how you described it is right. But I think what I'd suggest we do is take that offline and get one of our guys to go through it with you because it's an art rather than a science.
Okay. Thanks very much.
And the next question this morning comes from the line of Chintan Joshi from Nomura.

Hi, good morning. Apologies, I had a technical issue, so I might have missed some comments. My first question is on just what do you see as a picture in mortgages in the UK? If I look at SVRs of bank, they are north of 4%. Whereas if you look at two-year mortgages, you can get them now at 3.1%. So, are you seeing switching behavior from your customers to move from SVR to new lower-priced fixed deals? And how do you think about headwinds from this re-pricing?
Sorry, headwinds from?
From this re-pricing of moving from a 4%-plus SVR to a 3% new fixed rate deal.

Yes. I think maybe you missed the comment, but our view on mortgage pricing is that we will be competitive, and in particular, we want to look at the returns that we make on a product-by-product basis and look at whether it meets our return on equity requirements. The direction of travel that we're seeing is very low SVR volumes, mostly fixed and tracker, and increased numbers of buy to let, increased volumes, so really, across the board increase in volumes and good performance as a result of it.

Okay. Okay. The second question was on some of the targets that you've given. If I think about the £16.8 billion cost target, add to that the £700 million restructuring, with the mid-50s cost/income ratio, that seems to imply a 10% revenue growth for a 9% cost reduction. I'm just trying to tie the two together. What you're saying here is you'll grow revenues and yet cut costs by about 10% each.

Can I suggest we get ready to answer that question after the strategy session we're doing this morning and afternoon? Because one of the things we tackle is exactly how you get that cost performance line as you've been trying to derive. So it'd be easier done once we've released the slide packs and information later on today.
Fair enough. And just one final detail question, what was the driver of the quarter-on-quarter move in risk-weighted assets?
Particularly, the quarter-on-quarter was operational risk events that gave rise to an increase in RWAs.
Okay. Thank you.
And your next question today is from Gary Greenwood of Shore Capital.

Hi. It's Gary at Shore Capital. I just wanted to come back to the issue of bonuses because I didn't quite understand, given the sort of current hype around bonuses and banks' attitudes towards bonuses, why you've increased the current year cash bonus and again, why are you talking about reducing the amount of deferral? I'm a bit surprised. I would have thought the route to be going down would be the opposite of that.

Hi, Gary. It's Rich. It's a good question. I think what I'm referring to is we've had extraordinary events. We clearly have a conservative deferral profile, but because of some of the events we've had, we've increased deferrals. What you want to do is try and get the balance right between making sure the interests are aligned, but that you're not overloading your deferral rate in any one year. That's irrational for the shareholder, because you want to make sure. Because you have the constant roll in of deferrals, so if that rate is too high in any one year, if you're working to a cost to income – comp to income ratio, it could really limit your flexibility one way or the other.

So, it's about getting the balance right. And I think we just had a couple of extraordinary years where we've been particularly conservative in our deferral rate which might not be in the interest long term to the shareholder in terms of what we can pay the franchise versus pay them.
Surely it's the cash rather than the P&L that matters there?
Yes, of course.
It's both.

It's both. But the cash payments, we're not talking about a significant increase, the way we've skewed our deferrals this year, it's mostly toward the top of the house. So, we're trying to get the cash that is released into the hands of the more junior people in the organization.
Okay, thank you.
Thank you. And the next question today comes from the line of Christopher Wheeler from Mediobanca.

Yes, good morning. A question really I suspect for Rich I think and it's really looking at the fixed income trading numbers. I mean, if I look at the big banks who've reported to date, we see quarter-on-quarter the average decline as being 24%.
